subject: Re: The Software Inferno - Convincing management of the benefits of unit tests
msgSnippet: I m still not convinced of the economics of unit testing at the lowest level. I ve been lurking this list for quite some time, attended online
messageBody:
<controversial>

I'm still not convinced of the economics of unit testing at the
lowest level.
I've been lurking this list for quite some time, attended online and
offline seminars, listened to to Agile, XP and TDD talks, ...

And apply it at work.

I am convinced that TDD is a right approach.
I see big value in the agile methods.
But to my feeling unit testing can be done at the requirements level.

That's why I am thinking about testdriving this approach:

1: Write unit tests only to test the requirements.
2: Write the code that implements these requirements, until tests
pass.
3: Run the unit tests together with a code coverage tool
4: delete all executable lines of code not covered by the unit test

</controversial>

Regards, Jan
